respondent.name: JAMES R. MCDONOUGH, INTERIM SECRETARY, FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONS, ET AL.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Hill v. McDonough. Mr. Doss.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Which you decline to specify. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: By a means which you decline to specify, so that if they come up with some other means, you could -- you could object to that as well I assume.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, I understand that. But I'm just -- I'm just pointing out what -- what becomes available to you if we -- if we give you the relief you request.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You -- we -- we say this -- this procedure is no good. The State comes up with another procedure, and you challenge that one. Right? And -- and another few years go by. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You -- you think that the -- the way you would proceed in trial court is the trial court finds that this is no good, and -- and then the trial court proposes an alternative, or -- or invites the State to propose to the trial court an alternative, and then asks whether you agree to that alternative. And if you don't, the trial court makes the decision whether the alternative is -- is constitutional or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's not bad.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You're envisioning that one case will take care of it. That is, if the Court rules against you, that's the end of it. You can't come back with another inadequacy because you'd be barred by claim preclusion. On the other hand, if the State comes up with an acceptable alternative, you agree to it. That's one thing. The Court holds -- but there wouldn't be a second episode I think. One way or another this proceeding would end it.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that probably will be what will be alleged. Of course, you don't know when -- at this proceeding, we have no idea, if we rule in your favor, what alternative the State is going 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 to provide, and I am willing to bet whatever that alternative is that it will be subject to a challenge under a new 1983 suit. There would be no claim preclusion if you didn't know what the alternative was at this point. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In this very case, you're saying the court would -- would rule on the State's proposed alternative. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But if you disagreed with that, you could appeal it up again. Right? You can go to the court of appeals --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- and then seek cert up here. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: May -- just as a -- maybe this is technical, but what did you ask for for relief? Did you ask for relief that the State be enjoined from using this method, or that the State be enjoined from executing him until an acceptable method had been 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 found? Because in the first case, the door theoretically is open to seriatim 1983 actions, and in the second case, presumably the issue would be resolved in this one case, as you suggest. So which did you ask for? Injunction against this or injunction until an acceptable alternative came up?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, if that's -- if that's the relief you get, then the door would be open to successive different 1983 actions every time the State comes up with -- with a new protocol. Whereas, if what the -- if -- if the trial court -- if you succeed at this stage, if we say, yes, you're -- you're properly in court and you go ahead and litigate it, if the trial court, in fact, awards not the injunction that you asked for but the injunction saying do not execute this person until a constitutional protocol has been proposed and accepted by the court, then everything will get resolved in this one action, as you suggest. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 So would -- would you consent to -- as it were, to an amendment of your prayer for relief so that the injunction will be in such a form that everything can get resolved in this one case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You -- you would agree to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, do you have confidence --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You said --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- do you have confidence that Florida can do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Do you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, one -- one of the circumstances that -- that was raised by the questioning is this. States generally have the defense of laches. They -- they require the petition to be filed within a reasonable time. With changes in pharmacology, the laches defense will not usually be available. And under the proposal that the -- the State resolves it once and for all, I suppose the State couldn't adopt a new protocol that it thought was better, more humane, without risking more litigation. So it -- it really is a disincentive for the States to try to make the procedure less painful for the -- for the accused.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Precisely. And that's going to be true with every new protocol.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You said there were other States. You mentioned California. There was a proposal by the State. It couldn't be executed. What was the experience -- you mentioned a couple of other cases where the particular combination of drugs was successfully challenged, but then the State did what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Do you agree that that was 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 not a -- that method of execution is not a violation of the Eighth Amendment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Do you know of any method that has been used -- used throughout the country that is not a violation of the Eighth Amendment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is it only excruciating pain that the Eighth Amendment prohibits or is it any pain? Does the Eighth Amendment require painless execution?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, when you say wanton and gratuitous, you're -- you're saying any pain that can be eliminated must be eliminated. Otherwise, it's gratuitous I assume.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes. So if there's any way of -- of execution that is totally painless, that -- that must be pursued.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Where -- where do you derive that from? I mean, gee, you know, that -- that was 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 certainly never the principle evident in -- in executions in the past. Hanging was -- was not a -- you know, a quick and easy way to go. You would have thought they would have required a firing squad instead or something like that. I -- I just don't know where you're deriving this principle that there cannot be any pain associated with the execution.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I can understand excruciating pain, but -- but you -- you want to press it to the point where there can't be any pain associated. Any pain that can be eliminated must be eliminated. That seems to me a very extreme proposition.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No. I understand what you're challenging here. But what -- what alternative would be acceptable to you? Only one -- only one that -- that, to the maximum extent possible, eliminates all pain. Isn't that right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Would it be -- if -- if in the future, if States specify the method of 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 execution in the sentence, then you would not have a 1983 action. Is that correct? Because you would then be challenging the sentence, and it would have to be brought under habeas.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, but -- but you -- you -- their procedure was set forth in a -- in a notice, a regulation or something. You -- you had notice of what procedure they intended to use several years ago, didn't you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Now, you're saying they could change it in the future, but sure, of course. Any -- any agency can change its -- its regulations. But didn't you know that this is the procedure they intended to use several years ago?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you have to wait to -- you have to wait to the eve of execution before -- before you think you have a -- a ripe claim under -- under habeas.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Congress has the complete discretion to change the statutes it's enacted, but that doesn't mean that you can't change -- you can't challenge a statute now because it might be changed before -- before the action you want to take occurs. You can challenge it now. And it seems to me it's the same thing with the method of execution prescribed by -- by an administrative agency in -- in a State.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, what did they have? There was the Sims case. No -- no -- certainly not in the legislation. There's no rule that emerges. But you did know that there was a lethal injection procedure that had been prescribed for another prisoner, and yet you didn't challenge the lethal injection at that time. Why did you wait until so late?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Have they, in fact, changed the procedure for the lethal injection?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: When did you ask for the public -- when did you ask for the -- a -- a statement of the protocol that would be used in your case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't understand. How did you get into the court if you didn't know what protocol they were going to use?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You say you didn't know it until the 19th when your case was already in the court. What -- what were you challenging?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me. How did the trial court get into it? Does the records request go through -- through a trial court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What -- what is the -- the action that you're bringing? An action for records request?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: May -- may I ask you to clarify one thing? I take it, at this point, there 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 isn't any question about the -- the amounts and ingredients that will be used in -- if -- if the execution goes forward. But my recollection is that you said that your -- your request for a specification of this formula or protocol was denied by Florida. Did you ever, as a result of your records request or otherwise, get a statement directly from Florida to you that the following proportions of chemicals will be used?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But until you went into that proceeding, I take it, you had asked Florida to specify and Florida said, no, it would not do so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Did -- did you ever say to -- to any Florida official, please tell me what the chemicals are and the amounts that will be used --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- not asking for records, just asking for a statement about what they were going to do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But I guess before you went into court with a public records action, did you ever say to somebody, tell us what you're going to do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What -- what I'm getting at is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- there -- there are ways to find out. One would be to ask. One would be to chop the door down with an ax to find out if there's a 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 statement hidden inside. Did you ever try the easy way and simply say to them, will you specify for us what you're going to do and how you're going to do this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, you -- you alleged in your complaint -- I'm looking at footnote 3 -- that you assumed they were going to follow the same protocol as in Sims.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, they still do, but you're here. I mean, they -- they still have the opportunity to change it, but you're here challenging it even though it is still changeable. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Can I just clarify one thing for myself? Do I correctly understand that the Federal district court -- I'm not talking about the State court -- did not rule on the merits of your claim, but merely held that 1983 is not the proper method of pursuing the claim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So that there hasn't been a decision by a Federal judge on whether or not there's merit to your case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It's just a question of which -- whether you do it by way of habeas corpus or by 1983.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And I suppose it's entirely possible that if the judge then decided it is really -- if we said it should have been a 1983 action, the judge could say, well, okay, even under 1983 the State has the defense of laches and you still lose. I mean, you -- we don't know what's going to happen if we find out -- if we agree with what your argument in this Court is. Is that right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Ms. Snurkowski, we'll hear now from you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But there's no statute and there's no regulation that requires Florida to do that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But there is no statute, no regulation. That means the executive can do what it will. There's nothing that binds them to the way it was done in Sims' case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And I suppose that's -- that's the complaint. If there was a procedure in place, we could address it. If Florida reserves to itself the ability to change at any time, well, that's -- we want to be told what it will be in our particular case so we have a target that we can aim at.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But what he -- I -- I take it the ripeness issue is -- he delayed in bringing it because he wasn't certain what you'd do. And -- and one of the reasons, I think, would be that it's only recently there was an article in the Lancet --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- that says the -- in the opinion of the doctors who wrote it, a significant number of executed people are conscious when they die, and that's painful. And then it's been suggested there are ways around that. Just give them more sodium pentothal or have a doctor or somebody there to make certain the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 individual is unconscious at the time that the death- causing drugs take effect. All right. Now, that doesn't seem too difficult. Maybe it's difficult, but it doesn't seem too difficult. So why can't they think, you know, Florida -- they can read there too. They have people who read these articles, and indeed, maybe they'll just do it. They don't have any real interest in -- in causing suffering. Why don't they just do it? And so he thinks, up until the last minute, that maybe Florida will just do it, and lo and behold, when the death warrant is actually executed, it now begins to appear that they won't. And therefore, at that time, he brings the case. Now, I've spun out a story which seems probable, but if it's true, it would be very understandable why this wasn't ripe before the execution warrant is issued and thereafter it is. Now, what is your reply on the ripeness question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- my -- my little story was inaccurate as to Florida or accurate as to Florida.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is the kind of thing I was explaining why it would be ripe I think -- is that accurate enough for the purposes of ripeness as to what happened in Florida?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Would he have to come up 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- with, as you suggest, an alternative that would be acceptable? Suppose there had been a hearing and it was proved more probable than not that in some cases -- not in all, but in some cases -- use of this injection would cause excruciating pain. Would the Petitioner who is objecting being exposed to that have to come up with an alternative in order to avoid the risk of excruciating pain?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, my question to you is -- I take it you're answering yes, that if they prove that some people will be subject to excruciating pain, that's not good enough unless the Petitioner proposes an alternative, that it's all right for the State to expose someone to the risk of what has -- what has been determined to be the risk of excruciating pain 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 as long as the Petitioner himself doesn't come up with an alternative.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, because there's been no hearing. We've never gotten past is this -- can you open the door through 1983, and I -- I still don't understand what your answer is to my question. Now, I'm supposing that we do have the 1983 hearing, and the judge says, yes, I agree with the Petitioner's experts. In some cases there will be excruciating pain. Then you say, but, Judge, they haven't come up with an alternative. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And the judge says, you're both right. Some people have excruciating pain, but there's been no alternative suggested. Bottom line of that particular case would be?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So the answer is yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The court, having found that some people will be subject to excruciating pain, still no Eighth Amendment violation because the Petitioner hasn't come up with an alternative.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What is the source of his obligation to do this? I mean, why does he have an obligation under the Eighth Amendment or under any other ground to tell the State how to execute people?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That -- that was a fact in Nelson, but my question to you is if -- if we were to agree with you and say that that, in fact, is a -- is 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 an element of a 1983 action here, what would be the source of -- of the -- the conclusion that -- that he has to propose a less painful alternative?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No. But I mean, that's not -- that's not the issue. I'm not asking you about res judicata. I'm saying that if he comes into court and, as Justice Ginsburg suggested in her hypo, his experts demonstrate to the satisfaction of the fact finder that there will, in a certain number of cases, be excruciating pain, and he is at least within the risk of that, your response is we're still -- that is no grounds for enjoining the execution under 1983. We can still execute unless he comes up with a proposal for a less painful way of doing it. And what I want to know is, why does he have such an obligation? Why isn't it enough for him to show that there is a probability that he will suffer excruciating pain? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No. Justice Souter and Justice Ginsburg can protect their own questions. Part of that allegation in here is that the State wasn't forthcoming with the -- with -- with the information requested, and you're not very forthcoming with the answers. What is the source, what is the legal source, what is the precedent for the proposition that the -- that the condemned man has to come up with an alternative? What case do you cite? What principle do you cite?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's what we're asking.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But it was mentioned -- it was mentioned in Nelson. But what would be the reason for -- for elevating that -- that fact in Nelson to a 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 requirement? What is the legal principle that would support your argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But isn't there evidence in -- I noticed the brief filed by some veterinarians call our attention to the statute that prohibits the euthanasia of dogs and cats unless they follow a certain procedure. So there must have been a legislative feeling that unless that procedure were followed, there's a risk of undue pain to the dogs and cats. Why isn't there a similar basis for believing that if you don't follow a similar procedure that such a risk might be present for human beings?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And what's your response to it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But your procedure, if I understand it, would be prohibited to be applied to dogs or cats.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, at least it was sufficiently convincing to get the Florida legislature to pass a statute.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, I would have thought your -- your answer to the line of questioning earlier was that the reason that the Petitioner has to come up with this -- an alternative is that otherwise it's plausible, at least, to suspect the reason he's bringing the action is as a challenge to the execution itself rather than the particular method. And that if it's a challenge to the execution itself, it has to be brought under habeas. If it's just a challenge to the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 method, it can be brought under 1983. If he's unwilling to say there is a valid method, then it starts to look like a challenge to the execution that has to be brought under habeas.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But in respect to that core position, I can understand the State's concern with the possibility of abuse. But in Nelson, what the Court says is it points to Gomez, and Gomez was a 1983 case. And there, the Court denied a stay of the execution because it looked into the history of the litigation, and they said that this particular individual had done just what worries you, though in a somewhat different context. He kept bringing the cases, and every time, you know, he'd lose. Then he'd think of another way of making the same point, and in your context, it would be first he challenges this method and he says there are others that are fine. So we go to another. Then he challenges that. Then he challenges that. Then he challenges that, always at the very last minute. So there's a case that provides a weapon if the abuse that you worry about occurs. So why do we need something else like an 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 absolute rule of some sort that the Petitioner has to think of a method of execution, a matter on which he is not necessarily expert, that would turn out in the future to be not painful? I mean, you don't need to put on your overcoat and also turn up the heat.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You've got the case that helps you if that occurs. Why do you need to argue for something else?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Shanmugam, we'll hear now from you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why is that? Why is that? That -- that -- in which case it would be like -- like Heck. Right? It would come within the Heck principles.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well -- well, why? But I mean, suppose he doesn't. Okay? But it's absolutely clear he's not saying all methods are unconstitutional. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 He's saying this method is unconstitutional. If he says this method of constitutional and he wins, then his challenge will not necessarily prevent the State from carrying out its execution. And, of course, I'm reading to you directly from Nelson v. Campbell. That would seem right in point. And why isn't that the end of this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, and if I bring a claim that my prison cell is so cold, I actually get pneumonia and die, or near it, and then I challenge the coldness of the cell, I'm preventing my confinement in one particular way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's a cold cell. And so that would similarly, on your theory, be habeas, but we know it isn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: My cold cell is habeas? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why more than in Nelson?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I didn't -- I didn't get your explanation. Had you finished it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about the risks that the prisoner will die an excruciating death? I'm asking you the same question that I asked co-counsel. What happens then? He hasn't been able to come up with an alternative, but the judge finds it credible that he may be exposed to an excruciating death. What then?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But would --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why not? Because he's 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 saying I am not asking for this to be one day further along. I'm just asking the State to give me a death that will not require me to suffer excruciating pain.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Except -- let me just interrupt. Supposing he did identify, say you can only use pentobarbital on me, the same way they do it for a veterinarian. And the -- and the judge says, well, I don't think that's required. But he would then be satisfied the 1983 requirement?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Of saying no.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But do you agree if he had said I propose alternative X, even though it's highly 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 unlikely the State will accept it, that would make it a 1983 action?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Even though there's no functional difference in terms of future litigation between that case and this.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So you're saying -- saying then that the defense bar, the capital punishment bar, and the prisoners are the group of people that have to go and do the research on humane methods of putting people to death rather than the government.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That strikes me as a little odd, doesn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't think -- I don't think that's the research they would do. I think the research they would do would be to come up with another method that the State certainly would not find acceptable, thereupon, rendering it a 1983 action and -- and leaving everything in the same status that it's -- that it is here. I mean, I don't see that you've accomplished anything by simply demanding that they -- that they come up with an alternative. They're going to come up with a -- with an unacceptable alternative.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It -- it might be malpractice not to come up with -- with an unacceptable alternative. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Old age. They'll come with that alternative, old age. Right? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: This -- this is a death case. It was not that amusing. Let me ask you this. Doesn't the State have some minimal obligation under the Eighth Amendment to do the necessary research to assure that this is the most humane method possible? Doesn't the State have a minimal obligation on its own to do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I can define gratuitous -- I don't have the dictionary here. But gratuitous means essentially unnecessary. If there were other -- other means, other alternatives, that might be used, it seems to me that the State might have some minimal obligation to investigate those.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But is there -- is there in this case? I mean, the Lancet article has been out there for a while, and it certainly is enough to suggest, in your words, that there is something problematic about the manner in which Florida proposes to do this. And yet, we have not heard a word that Florida has made any effort whatsoever to find an alternative or, for that matter, to -- to disprove what the Lancet article suggests. And so it's one thing for you to say the States have discretion. I don't think that answers Justice Kennedy's question as to why the State does not have an obligation to fulfill its constitutional duty to execute without gratuitous pain. And I don't see why you have given any answer to -- to the proposal that that obligation requires the State to do some investigation of it's own.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We've -- we've never held that anyway, have we?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That the State must, in -- in imposing the death penalty, use a method that inflicts the least amount of pain.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And presumably there's some range between most humane and what's cruel and unusual. Right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Shanmugam, several of the emergency death proceedings we've had involving this question, the district court judges have assumed that it could proceed under 1983 but then denied relief because it was brought on the eve of execution, as this one was. Is that option available to the district court in this case if it's sent back?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Doss, you have 5 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You know it -- it is true that the 1983 is a civil action, and the plaintiff has the burden of proof, burden of producing evidence.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you think there was adequate time for the district court to fully consider the evidence you intended to present and consider your claim and still proceed with the execution that was scheduled?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You filed your case 4 days before the execution.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The Sims protocol was there as a matter of public domain. You said in your complaint yourself, when you didn't get any 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 information, you said, well, I assume they're going to follow Sims. Why wasn't that assumption valid 3 months before, 6 months before, or a year before?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, it seems to me that you might -- you might have alleged that -- that you've read articles, Lancet articles, and so forth, and that there is a substantial risk that they're going to do this. I think that might suffice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And -- and it would -- it would mean that the -- as the Chief Justice indicates, the court has more time to look at this.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Suppose you -- suppose you never were told by Florida what the -- how exactly it was going to be done. Does that mean you never could have brought a 1983 claim even on the day -- the scheduled day of execution?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Suppose -- suppose they did set it forth but reserved the right to change it. They promulgated a regulation without public notice, without hearings or anything. This is our regulation. This is how we intend to conduct executions in the future. Period. We reserve the right to change this. Would you claim that -- that this was not ripe? You couldn't challenge it at that point --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- because they could change 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No. This is the current method that we intend to use in all future executions. Period. We may change our mind.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Don't -- don't you think you -- you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- don't you think effectively had that knowledge when you knew -- knew about Sims and you knew about all of the cases after Sims? Is that very much short of -- of their saying this is the -- the procedure we intend to use?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I -- I understand your -- your argument to be -- and I don't think you're making it here, but I understood your argument elsewhere to be 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 we knew about Sims, but when they stonewalled us and said we won't tell you what we're going to use, we had reason to question whether they were going to follow Sims. Isn't -- isn't that your point?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No. You alleged the exact opposite in footnote 3. You said when they stonewalled you, we assumed they were going to follow Sims.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Finish.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
